app.name: Uptime Kuma
app.one_liner: A fancy self-hosted monitoring tool for tracking uptime of various services.

screens.name: Dashboard
screens.purpose: Display real-time status of all configured monitors with visual indicators, tags, and groupings.

screens.name: Status Pages
screens.purpose: Provide public or private status pages that can be mapped to specific domains and sorted by name, tags, or uptime.

screens.name: Notifications
screens.purpose: Configure and manage notification integrations across 90+ services including Discord, Telegram, Email, and PagerDuty.

rust_commands.name: save_monitor_config
rust_commands.purpose: Persist monitor configuration including type, interval, and notification settings.

rust_commands.name: send_notification_alert
rust_commands.purpose: Dispatch alert to configured notification providers when monitor status changes.

rust_commands.name: check_domain_expiry
rust_commands.purpose: Verify domain certificate expiry and trigger notifications only if TLD supports RDAP.

mvp_plan: week 1: Implement core monitor types: HTTP, Ping, DNS
week 1: Add basic notification support (Discord, Email)
week 1: Persist data to local SQLite database
week 2: Support monitor grouping and tagging
week 2: Implement status pages with sorting
week 2: Add domain expiry monitoring with RDAP check
acceptance_tests: Given a monitor is down, when the system detects failure, then a notification is sent via configured provider with correct title and metadata.
Given a status page exists, when user selects sort by 'uptime', then monitors are reordered by descending uptime percentage.
Given a domain with unsupported TLD, when domain expiry check runs, then no expiry notification is triggered.
Given a Browser Engine monitor, when screenshot delay option is set, then the system waits specified time before capturing screenshot.
